Now that they doe So, will further appear by the affinity of 
their properties: As that the infusion of <s>Hepretic<\s> Nephritic wood and many 
other Substances reflect one colour, and transmitt another, like 
thin bodyes in the 9th & 20th Observac[i]ons: That the colours of 
Silks, Clothes & other Substances, wch water or oyle can intimately 
penetrate, become more faint & obscure by being im[m]erged in those 
Liquors, & recover their Vigour againe by being dryed, much after 
the manner declared of thin bodyes in the 10th & 21th Observac[i]ons.
And that Some of those coloured Powders, wch Painters use may 
haue their colours a little changed by being very elaborately & finely 
ground. Where I See not, what can be justly pretended for those 
changes, besides the breaking of their parts into less parts by that 
contric[i]on, after the Same manner that the colour of a Plate is 
changed by varying its thickness. For wch reason also it is, that many 
Flowers by being Bruised become more transparent then before, or at 
least in Some degree or other change their colours. Nor is it much 
lesse to  my purpose, that by mixing divers liquors very odd and 
remarkable productions & changes of colours may be effected, of wch 
no cause can be more obvious & Naturall, then that the Saline 
corpuscles of one liquor do variously act upon or unite with 
the tinging Corpuscles of another, So as to make them Swell or
Shrink (whereby not onely their bulk but their density alsoe 
may be changed) or to divide them into Smaller corpuscles, or 
make many of them associate into one cluster; For wee See,
how apt those Saline Menstruums are to penetrate & dissolue 
Substances to wch they are applyed, and Some of them to precipitate 
what others dissolue. In like manner, if wee consider the various 
Phaenomene of the Atmosphere, wee may observe, that when 
vapours are first raised, they hinder not the transparency of the 
Air, being divided into parts too small to cause any reflexion in 
their Superficies: But, when in Order to compose drops of raine 
they begin to coalesce and constitute Globules + when they become 
of a convenient Size to reflect Some colours & transmitt 
others, may constitute Clouds of various colours according to their 
Sizes. And I see not, what can be rationally conceived in so 
transparent a Substance as water for the production of these 
colours, besides the various Sizes of its parcells, wch Seeme to 
affect a globular figure most; but yet p[er]haps not without Some 
instability in the smallest of them, by reason that those are most 
easily agitated by heat or any trembling motions in the Air.
